title: How to embed images into HTML - Quora

response.answer_text: You can encode the image data in base64, which drastically increases the file size (to 4/3rds the original size) but serializes the binary data in a text-safe format. So you just include it in the HTML as such:  To base64 encode a file on a *nix system (such as OS X or Linux), you can use the base64 command: base64 -i "myimage.jpg" or: base64 -i "myimage.jpg" -o "base64.txt" There are also online encoders you can find on Google, but I don't know what their file size limits are. Also, note that different browsers have different max sizes for data URLs. For IE8, it’s 32 kb. For Opera 11, it’s 65 kb. Firefox has, in theory, no limit (though in practice I’m sure there is some kind of limit that you’re simply unlikely to reach). Chrome’s limit is 5MB, I think. Per usual, see the Mozilla Developer Network for more details: Data URLs.
